ygData.subject: Re: ANJI : NEAT implementation (fingerprint implementation issues)
ygData.msgSnippet: Here are my thoughts after reading through this very interesting conversation. First, I agree rotation is an important issue for HyperNEAT; however, I am

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=pkwyQ-ej5kQbNYuCFvqGCAoMXCpd7qEKyGZEx9P0Gt6Z4w7IUswl

Here are my thoughts after reading through this very interesting 
conversat=
ion.

First, I agree rotation is an important issue for HyperNEAT; however,=
 
I am confident that is can be dealt with.  It's an interesting open 
rese=
arch problem.

In any case, there is an important aspect of this issue that=
 we 
should also be considering.  The problem is not simply to be able to 
=
perform a rotation. As Jason's posts imply (and Peter stated), 
HyperNEAT a=
nd CPPNs should technically already be able to perform 
rotations.  And, in=
 fact, they do.  When I play with God Mode in 
genetic art I often find wei=
ghts that when adjusted rotate a part of 
the image.  That is not that unus=
ual (although perhaps not as usual 
as we'd like either).

However, that ki=
nd of rotation actually *isn't* the type we really 
need.  The issue is not=
 that a particular shape should be possible to 
rotate some arbitrary angle=
 by changing some weights. Recall that 
CPPNs work by laying out coordinate=
 frames within which higher 
strucutres are situated.  To create a symmetri=
c coordinate frame means
creating a gradient with *two* sides, both the opp=
osite of each 
other.  That is, symmetry is not created by flipping a gradi=
ent from 
one side to the other, but rather by having both sides at the sam=
e 
time.

Therefore, a rotational coordinate frame should actually contain =

something akin to a sinusoidal gradient that spreads around a circle 
rath=
er than along a line. Then, structures situated within its 
coordinate fram=
e would repeat in a rotated regular pattern, like 
petals on a flower (that=
 way you get rotatonal invariance).  

Thus what we really want is to be ab=
le to feed in a regular 2D 
coordinate frame and output another coordinate =
frame that is a sine 
wave around a circle in 2D as well.  In other words:
=

f(x,y)=3Da point in this circular petal-like gradient

Thus we only need t=
o define a function like that and make it an 
activation function that take=
s two distinct inputs.

However, the problem does remain of where to contro=
l the period of 
repetition around the circle.

Actually, thinking of it no=
w, what we really want is NOT what I just 
said but rather something a bit =
different that would solve the 
problem I just posed: What we want is a fun=
ction f(x,y) that produces 
a gradient that starts at 0 on e.g. the x axis =
and then increases up 
to 1 as you rotate around the origin to 360 degrees.=


That way, you have a true circular/polar coordinate system.  Then you 
ca=
n simply run its output into a sine wave, and you get the 
repetition aroun=
d the circle that I describe above.  Then the 
frequency of repetition is c=
ontrolled very easily by varying the 
weight leaving the polar function and=
 entering the sine wave, just 
as in any normal CPPN!

So I guess my conclu=
sion is we just need a function that converts 
Cartesian coordinates to a p=
olar angle, and then running its output 
into a periodic activation functio=
n will give your nice rotational 
repetition, which in a neural substrate i=
s rotational invariance!

Hmm...so I think this explains in part how to dea=
l with the issue, 
though maybe not 100% (it doesn't explain what it means =
if the inputs 
to such a polar conversion function are not the base-level x=
 and y, 
but I think such cases will actually yield nice localized rotation=
al 
effects as well).  

Sorry for writing out my thoughts as they come to =
me in stream of 
consciousness- this is a rare case where I'm thinking of i=
deas as I 
write!

ken

e's inputs into 2 branches, say 
we
> > > have 4 inputs into the node, and =
2 outputs from it, we can 
assign
> > > those 4 inputs (divide them by 2, s=
o 2 will sum together
> > > independently of the others) to a "X" entrance =
and a "Y" 
entrance,
> > > and then, after computing the rotation, output r=
esults to 
the "X"
> > > exit and "Y" exit. If there is only one output con=
nection, then
> > > use "X" only, or maybe "X+Y" or whatever...
> > >
> > >=
 I think the second suggestion is better. What do you think?
